title: shallow rendering propTypes validation
body:
``` javascript
const React = require('react')

function scopedForWarnings(i) {
    const C = () => React.createElement('div')
    C.displayName = 'C'+i
    C.propTypes = {c: React.PropTypes.string.isRequired}

    const B = () => React.createElement(C)
    B.displayName = 'B'+i
    B.propTypes = {b: React.PropTypes.string.isRequired}

    const A = () => React.createElement(B)
    A.displayName = 'A'+i

    return React.createElement(A)
}

console.log('Shallow rendering')
require('react-addons-test-utils').createRenderer().render(scopedForWarnings(1))

console.log('Static markup rendering')
require('react-dom/server').renderToStaticMarkup(scopedForWarnings(2))
```

Actual:

```
Shallow rendering
Warning: Failed propType: Required prop `b` was not specified in `B1`.
Static markup rendering
Warning: Failed propType: Required prop `b` was not specified in `B2`. Check the render method of `A2`.
Warning: Failed propType: Required prop `c` was not specified in `C2`. Check the render method of `B2`.
```

Expected (unless I'm mistaken :cry: ):

```
Shallow rendering
Static markup rendering
Warning: Failed propType: Required prop `b` was not specified in `B2`. Check the render method of `A2`.
Warning: Failed propType: Required prop `c` was not specified in `C2`. Check the render method of `B2`.
```

We are working towards 0 warnings for our React components tests, and I thought just using shallow would allow us to stop mocking/passing tons of useless props for propTypes validation.

But the first level of component, even though it's not "really" rendered, propTypes validation still occurs, is that normal ?
